meanings.definition: To move sideways, especially in a shy or sneaky manner.
meanings.sent1: The cat sidled up to the mouse, trying to catch it off guard.
meanings.sent2: She sidled past the group of people, hoping not to be noticed.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel sidled towards the bird feeder, hoping for a snack.
meanings.sent4: The shadow sidled along the wall, following the unsuspecting figure.
meanings.sent5: The spy sidled into the room, blending in with the crowd.

meanings.sent1: The thief sidled towards the open window, ready to make his escape.
meanings.sent2: He sidled closer to the door, listening for any sounds inside.
meanings.sent3: The raccoon sidled up to the trash can, looking for a late-night snack.
meanings.sent4: The fog sidled through the trees, enveloping everything in a mysterious haze.
meanings.sent5: The stranger sidled up to the group, trying to eavesdrop on their conversation.

meanings.definition: To walk in a timid or sneaky manner.
meanings.sent1: The child sidled towards the cookie jar, hoping not to wake anyone.
meanings.sent2: She sidled down the hallway, trying to avoid being seen by her siblings.
meanings.sent3: The penguin sidled across the ice, careful not to slip.
meanings.sent4: The ghostly figure sidled through the abandoned house, making no sound.
meanings.sent5: The ninja sidled past the guards, unseen and unheard.
